bio:treatment.discussion: Pinus washoensis often occurs in large stands and resembles P . jeffreyi . The number and posture of seed-cone scales fall within the ranges given for P . jeffreyi . The abaxial surface of these scales has a significantly darker pigmentation, however; such a color contrast is not apparent in P . jeffreyi . Forest geneticists have developed hybrids between P . washoensis and related yellow pines, but no natural hybrids have been observed. Some workers regard P . washoensis as closely related to---or even conspecific with--- P . ponderosa .
